1.content: Rudyard Kipling publishes White Man’s Burden, using Social Darwinist theory to justify European and U.S. colonization

2.content: After wealthy U.S. businessmen and landowners supported a coup of Queen Liliuokalani, Hawaii is annexed by the U.S.

3.content: The USS Maine is sunk in Cuba’s Havana Harbor, leading the U.S. into the Spanish-American War.

4.content: Platt Amendment reserved the U.S. right to intervene in Cuba when it saw fit

5.content: The anti-foreigner Boxer Rebellion in China was put down, leading to an expansion of trade between China and other nations

6.content: Teddy Roosevelt declares the Philippine- American War over, though brutal fighting continues against Filipino rebels for more than 10 years.

7.content: Teddy Roosevelt sends the Great White Fleet around the world to project U.S. naval strength

8.content: The Roosevelt Corollary to the Monroe Doctrine articulates that the U.S. would intervene to restore stability in the western hemisphere.

9.content: Following its support of Panamanian independence from Colombia, the U.S. takes over the Panama Canal project.

10.content: A German U-boat torpedoed and sank the RMS Lusitania, a British ocean liner going from New York to Liverpool, England.

11.content: Changing its isolationist attitude, the U.S. under Woodrow Wilson officially declares war on Germany and enters World War I.

12.content: In its Schenck v. U.S. case, the Supreme Court decides that the government can severely restrict freedom of speech in wartime.

13.content: The League of Nations is created in the wake of World War I without the U.S. joining.

14.content: Part of a larger Red Scare, the Palmer Raids begin, targeting mostly Italian and Eastern European immigrants suspected of being radical leftists.

15.content: Sacco and Vanzetti are executed for murder despite claims that the two were unfairly treated due to their anarchist political beliefs.

16.content: Margaret Sanger founds the American Birth Control League, which later became Planned Parenthood.

17.content: Harlem Renaissance poet Langston Hughes denounces racial prejudice in his “The Negro Artist and the Racial Mountain”

18.content: Ernest Hemingway opens his novel The Sun Also Rises with “You are all a lost generation”, popularizing the term in the wake of World War I’s devastation

19.content: The Eighteenth Amendment goes into effect on New Year’s Day, beginning over a decade of Prohibition.

20.content: The National Origins Act is passed, severely limiting immigration from S. and E. Europe and almost entirely excluding Asian immigration.

21.content: The Scopes Monkey Trial energizes religious fundamentalists, pushing evolutionary theory out of classrooms until the Space Race.

22.content: The stock market crashes, exposing deep and systemic weaknesses in the U.S. economy, eventually signalling the start of the Great Depression.

23.content: Nine African American teenagers known as the Scottsboro Boys are falsely accused and convicted of rape in Alabama.

24.content: Steinbeck’s The Grapes of Wrath is published, dramatizing the plight of “Okies” fleeing the Dust Bowl in search of opportunity in California.

25.content: President Hoover disperses World War I veterans known as the Bonus Army, who came to D.C. demanding compensation owed them

26.content: In one of his first actions as president, FDR declares a Bank Holiday in an effort to restore confidence in the U.S. banking system.

27.content: After more than a decade of troubled attempts at enforcement, Prohibition is repealed in the midst of the Great Depression.

28.content: The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is formed with the goal of regulating the stock market and protecting investors.

29.content: The Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) is created as a work relief program for unemployed, unmarried men.

30.content: The Social Security Act is established as a safety-net system of benefits for elderly workers, the physically disabled, and others.

31.content: The National Labor Relations Act (aka, Wagner Act) is passed becomes law, protecting the right of workers to organize into unions

32.content: After the Supreme Court ruled unfavorably on some New Deal programs, FDR’s court-packing plan failed to pass Congress in this year.

33.content: The Fair Labor Standards Act establishes a federal minimum wage, sets rules for overtime pay, and prohibits “oppressive child labor”.

34.content: The Committee on Public Information is created to publicize the U.S. government’s version of war events

35.content: Charles Lindbergh became a sensation when he made the first solo transatlantic flight

36.content: The United States of America men’s soccer team wins the World Cup.
